title: 111_hr3397
content: The "Northern Mariana Islands College Access Act of 2009" aims to provide college-bound residents of the Northern Mariana Islands with more options for higher education through a grant program for public schools. The Governor awards grants to eligible institutions to cover the difference in tuition for in-State and out-of-State students, with a maximum of $15,000 per year and $75,000 in total. Payments are prorated for students attending eligible institutions. The Governor may reduce tuition and fee payments for eligible students if funds are insufficient, first for those who haven't received funds before, then for all other eligible students. The Governor, in consultation with the Secretary of Education, may adjust tuition and fee payments based on financial need or administrative burdens. The Governor can also prioritize payments based on the income and need of eligible students. Eligible institution refers to a public four-year higher education institution. The eligible institution must be a public four-year higher education institution located in a State, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, or Guam, eligible for student financial assistance programs under title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965, and must enter into an agreement with the Governor to use funds to supplement assistance for eligible students from the Northern Mariana Islands. An eligible student is an individual who meets specified criteria. An eligible student from the Northern Mariana Islands must have been domiciled there for 12 consecutive months before starting college, graduated from a local secondary school after January 1, 2008, and begin undergraduate studies within three years. An eligible student must have graduated from a secondary school or obtained an equivalent diploma, be enrolled in a program leading to a recognized credential at an eligible institution, and maintain satisfactory progress in their course of study. The curr_chunk provides definitions for terms such as "institution of higher education," "Governor," "secondary school," and "Secretary" in relation to the Higher Education Act of 1965. The Secretary of Education is defined as the Secretary in this Act. Institutions of higher education are not required to change admissions policies for eligible students. Students must apply for tuition payment with the institution. The Governor administers the program in consultation with the Secretary. The Governor, in consultation with eligible institutions, develops policies and procedures for the program under this section. A Memorandum of Agreement between the Governor and the Secretary outlines consultation and assistance for program administration. The Governor develops policies for the program and reports annually to Congress on eligible students attending institutions, grant awards, tuition payments, and academic progress. The Comptroller General will monitor the program's impact on educational opportunities for eligible students, analyze difficulties in gaining admission to eligible institutions, and report findings to Congress and the Governor. Additionally, they will assess the availability of eligible institutions for Northern Mariana Islands students, considering caps on out-of-State student enrollment. The institution will enroll despite significant barriers like academic entrance requirements and absence of admission programs for minority students. A report on the findings and assessment will be submitted to Congress and the Governor. $15,000,000 is authorized for the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands annually from 2010 to 2015 for this purpose. Effective Date: This section applies to payments for instruction starting on or after January 1, 2010. SEC. 4. ASSISTANCE TO THE NORTHERN MARIANA COLLEGE. The Secretary of Education provides financial assistance to Northern Marianas College for vocational training programs in areas like food preparation and culinary arts. The Secretary of Education provides financial assistance to Northern Marianas College for vocational training programs in areas such as hospitality management, carpentry, electrical skills, plumbing, and other construction skills. The funds can be used for personnel hiring, faculty and staff salaries, rental of office and classroom space, purchase of furniture and equipment, climate control of facilities, and maintenance of equipment. Authorization of $2,000,000 annually for the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands for facility and equipment maintenance from 2010 to 2015. SEC. 5. GENERAL REQUIREMENTS. The Secretary of Education assigns an adviser to the Governor for program assistance. The Governor can use up to 5% of funds for administrative expenses. Programs under this Act are subject to Inspector General review. The Governor can accept donations for Act implementation. The Governor can adjust maximum student amounts for eligible students transferring between institutions under this Act.
